etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in Alexander Henry (1739–1824). Apparently from North American French bardache, †berdache, transferred use of French bardache, probably on account of European associations between transvestism and homosexuality

definitions: Among certain North American Indian peoples: a person (usually a man) who is recognized as having adopted a gender role intermediate between those traditionally associated with men and women. Later also in extended use with reference to other societies.

notes.text: Formerly widely adopted as an anthropological term, but now increasingly regarded as problematic, and avoided.
